componenttext: Good morning. My name is Bonnie, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Iron Mountain First Quarter 2010 Earnings Call Webcast. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Mr. Golden, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome, everyone to our 2010 first quarter earnings conference call. After my announcement this morning, Brian McKeon will review our financial results followed by Bob Brennan's CEO remarks. When Bob is finished with his comments, we will
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome, everyone to our 2010 first quarter earnings conference call. After my announcement this morning, Brian McKeon will review our financial results followed by Bob Brennan's CEO remarks. When Bob is finished with his comments, we will open up the phones for Q&A. Per our custom, we have a user-controlled slide presentation on the Investor Relations page of our website at www.ironmountain.com.
Referring now to Slide 2. Today's earnings call and slide presentation will contain a number of forward-looking statements, most notably, our outlook for our 2010 financial performance. All forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties. Please refer to today's press release, the Safe Harbor language on this slide and our most recently filed annual report on Form 10-K for a discussion of the major risk factors that could cause our actual results to be materially different from those contemplated in our forward-looking statements.
As a reminder, on our last earnings call we introduced two new metrics, adjusted OIBDA and adjusted EPS as part of our ongoing efforts to enhance our investor communications. We use several non-GAAP measures when presenting our financial results. Adjusted OIBDA, adjusted EPS and free cash flow before acquisitions and investments, among others, our metrics we speak to frequently and ones we believe to be important in evaluating our overall financial performance. We provide additional information and a reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures to the appropriate GAAP measures as required by Reg G at the Investor Relations page of our website, as well as in today's press release. With that, I would like to introduce our CFO, Brian McKeon.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steven. Slide 3 highlights the key messages from today's review. We posted solid results on the first quarter of 2010. Revenue growth of 7% was in line with expectations. Storage internal growth was solid at 4%. Service internal growth was 5% as s
componenttext:
Thanks, Steven. Slide 3 highlights the key messages from today's review. We posted solid results on the first quarter of 2010. Revenue growth of 7% was in line with expectations. Storage internal growth was solid at 4%. Service internal growth was 5% as strength in complementary service revenues, including benefits from higher paper prices, offset continued softness in core services. As we work to strengthen our revenue growth, we continue to drive strong profit and free cash flow performance. 
For the quarter, we delivered adjusted OIBDA growth of 11% driven by gross margin expansion of nearly 200 basis points. This expansion continues to be supported by productivity and pricing gains. Profit gains and capital efficiencies drove year-to-date free cash flow of $54 million. 
Adjusted EPS for the quarter was $0.23 per share, an increase of 19% compared to the same period last year. Our reported EPS was $0.12 per share, including the impacts of the higher effective tax rate and the change in fiscal year end for Iron Mountain Europe from October 31 to December 31. I'll discuss these items more fully later on my remarks. 
Overall, Q1 was a solid start to the year, and we're on track towards delivering strong full year financial performance, consistent with the goals shared on our Q4 earnings call. We are refining our guidance today to include the expected impacts of the recent earthquakes on our Chilean business, including items such as insurance deductibles and remediation costs. 
Let's now turn to Slide 4 and begin our review of the first quarter results. Slide 4 compares our results for this quarter to the first quarter of 2009. As I mentioned, revenues for the quarter were up 7% to $777 million. From a segment perspective, North American Physical posted 4% internal growth supported by 4% storage internal growth and strong complementary service revenue performance. Overall gains were constrained by continued pressures on core service activity levels, including impacts from unusually severe winter weather in several major markets. 
Our International Physical segment reported 6% internal growth supported by solid 8% growth in core revenues. These gains were moderated by declines in complementary revenues due primarily to lower project activity.
In our Digital segment, reported revenue growth was 3% for the first quarter including benefits from the Mimosa acquisition we completed at the end of February. Internal growth for this segment was minus 1% as eDiscovery gains were offset by impacts from lower subscription sales in recent quarters. 
Sustainable benefits from productivity initiatives and pricing gains, particularly in our North American Physical segment, drove higher service gross margins supporting a 190 basis points improvement in our consolidated gross margin. Higher storage gross margins, aided by improved pricing in North American Physical and gains in our International Physical business, were also key contributor to gross margin improvement.
Adjusted OIBDA grew 11% driven by strong gross profit gains. Below the adjusted OIBDA line, depreciation was $76 million and amortization was $9 million, in line with our forecast. Other expense for the quarter was $9 million, including $5 million of charges related to foreign currency rate changes and a $4 million one-time charge related to the change in Iron Mountain Europe's fiscal year from October 31 to December 31. This charge represents the net impact of this change for the two years ended December 31, 2009. There were no other effects from this change in our P&L.
Adjusted EPS for the quarter was $0.23 per share, an increase of 19% compared to the prior year reflecting strong operating performance and flat year-on-year interest expense. Reported EPS for the first quarter was $0.12 per share. The reported earnings were impacted by a higher effective tax rate reflecting the impact of discreet items, which more than offset higher pretax income. The structural tax rate for the first quarter was 39% as the impact of expired cash legislation was less than originally expected. The impact of discrete tax items primarily related to foreign currency rate changes in the quarter added 23 points to the effective tax rate. We expect the structural tax rate for 2010 to be 39%. 
Let's now take a closer look at our revenue growth on Slide 5. Slide 5 breaks down our overall revenue growth. It shows internal growth by major service line, as well as the impact of acquisitions and foreign exchange. As noted, our total internal growth for the quarter was 4%. Storage internal growth was solid at 4%, while complementary service revenues rebounded from a difficult 2009 to post 17% internal growth in Q1. These gains were offset by continued pressures on core service activity levels. Storage revenues, which represent more than 56% of total revenues continue to provide an expanding foundation for overall revenue performance. 
Storage revenue internal growth was 4%, with gains moderated by economic effects, which have constrained storage volume growth in recent quarters. Our service internal growth was flat for the first quarter. Growth rates were limited by lower activity levels, which remain pressured by economic conditions. We're planning for continued softness in core service activity given recent trends, as well as the select impacts from service reductions related to the Chilean earthquakes.
Overall, service revenues grew 5% reflecting strong growth in complementary service revenues supported by recent gains in recycled paper pricing. 
While paper price levels remain well above 2009 levels, they recently retreated about 15% from February, March levels, which were less than future gains. Foreign exchange increase reported revenue growth by 3% in the quarter reflecting the year-over-year weakening of the U.S. dollar. That current exchange rates' positive effects from foreign currency will moderate as we move forward.  
The Mimosa acquisition had minimal impact in our revenue growth in Q1 due to the timing of the close. Looking ahead, Mimosa should add just under 1% to our reported revenue growth each quarter. 
Let's now turn to Slide 6 to review our performance on a segment basis. Slide 6 shows key metrics for each of our core segments compared to Q1 of 2009. As a reminder, we have distinct goals and roles for our business segments within our integrated strategy. The North American Physical segment is the key financial driver of the business. We're capitalizing on our core opportunities to expand its high return foundation. 
In the International Physical segment, we're expanding our capabilities globally through a balanced approach focused on driving strong growth and improved returns. And in our Digital segment, we're investing to drive accelerated growth in attractive incremental markets. As shown in the slide, our Physical businesses continued to deliver strong operating performance. 
North America, our largest segment, continues to drive strong profits and cash flow. We're advancing our optimization agenda, while expanding our foundation through a targeted growth strategy. We have several programs aimed at driving improved revenue growth, and our field leadership is focused on supporting this effort with the same rigor they use to drive operational excellence.
Our International segment is performing well with solid revenue growth and improved profitability. We're beginning to leverage the success we had with operational excellence in North America and our larger more-developed international markets. Changes in the year-on-year exchange rates increased our reported results in this segment by approximately 8%. Please note that CapEx, which was 14% of segment revenues in Q1, includes about $11 million incurred by Iron Mountain Europe in November and December of 2009. 
In our Digital segment, we're working through some of the effects of softer subscription revenues in recent quarters and growth, while investing to advance our long-term strategic agenda. The integration of Mimosa is progressing well, and we'll enhance our service offering in support of accelerated digital growth. 
Let's turn to Slide 7 for a more detailed look at our capital spending and free cash flow. Slide 7 summarizes our capital spending and our free cash flow on a year-to-date basis. Total capital spending was $57 million for Q1, including $3 million for real estate. As I just mentioned, included in the total is $11 million of CapEx that was incurred by Iron Mountain Europe during November and December of 2009. 
Traditionally, the first quarter is a light CapEx quarter as some of our projects was scheduled for later in the year, and many required time to plan and source before the significant expenditures are eventually made. We remained focused on aggressively driving efficiencies in our capital spending, while supporting key growth initiatives and projects that help drive long-term return improvement. 
For Q1, the free cash flow before acquisitions and discretionary investments in real estate was $54 million. The year-on-year decrease in free cash flow was a result of higher capital spending in 2009 compared to 2010. This is due primarily to a large accrued balance at December 31, 2009 and the inclusion of the additional two months of CapEx from Europe.
For 2010, we expect free cash flow before acquisitions and discretionary investments in real estate to be approximately $340 million to $370 million, reflecting continued benefits from our efforts to improve profitability and capital efficiency.
As we announced in our Q4 earnings call in February, our Board approved a $150 million share repurchase program. In the first quarter, we acquired 410,000 shares for approximately $11 million. This leaves us a balance of $139 million for additional share repurchases under the existing plan. 
Let's now turn to Slide 8 for a review of our key debt statistics. Our strong performance supports the continued strengthening of our balance sheet. Our debt portfolio at March 31, 2010, remained in a very strong position. Our weighted average interest rate at 6.9% and were 87% fixed. Maturity is just under eight years with no meaningful repayment obligations until 2014. Consolidated leverage remained at 3.4x, benefiting from our strong operating cash flows while reflecting the $112 million we paid for the acquisition of Mimosa. 
Our liquidity position remains strong at more than $1 billion with $325 million in cash and $743 million in additional borrowing capacity as of quarter end. Currently, we have a very strong balance sheet, and we're well positioned in terms of the cash and financing capacity.
This concludes our review of Q1 2010 results. In summary, revenue performance was in line with expectations, we're driving continued strong profit and cash flow performance through sustainable productivity and pricing gains and we remain committed to strengthening our business foundation globally, while delivering strong financial performance. And we're on track towards these goals in 2010. 
Let's now turn to Slide 9 to review our outlook for Q2 and the full year. Slide 9 summarizes our full year 2010 and Q2 guidance. Let me begin with the discussion of our outlook for next quarter. 
For Q2, we're projecting revenue of $785 million to $805 million. This reflects a 5% to 8% reported growth rate, including an estimated 2% to 3% benefit from foreign exchange. While we are planning for continued solid storage growth, our outlook incorporates expectations for lower service revenue growth in Q2. We expect continued near-term pressure on core service activity, and we'll be facing some difficult comparisons as we lap a large one-time license sale on Digital and a large project in Europe. These factors will likely limit service revenue gains overall in Q2, and constrain the overall internal growth to the 2% to 4% range. Growth rates in the second half are expected to improve as the comparisons ease.
We're protecting Q2 adjusted OIBDA of $218 million to $228 million, reflecting expectations for sustained strong adjusted OIBDA margins. For the full year, we're reinforcing the solid fundamental outlook we discussed in our last conference call. We have reduced the dollar ranges of revenue by $5 million and adjusted OIBDA by $5 million to $10 million to reflect the impacts of the Chilean earthquakes in our full year results.  
As a result of the Chilean earthquakes, we experienced some damage in all of our facilities in the region. None of our facility were destroyed by fire or impacted by water damage. However, the structural integrity of 5 buildings was compromised and wrecking including certain buildings was damaged or destroyed. 
The adjustments we're making to our full year guidance reflect our expectations for loss, revenues and profits as the business works to return to normal, as well as the additional insurance and remediation costs associated with those efforts. For the enterprise, our full year outlook for reported revenue growth remains in the range of 6% to 8% supported by internal growth of 4% to 6%. 
Our revenue outlook reflects the expectations for solid storage growth this year consistent with prior guidance. We are targeting improved growth overall in the business in the second half of 2010, following some tougher comparisons in Q1 and Q2. We would note that performance at the high end of the revenue range will require improvement in current trends for service revenues in the second half of this year. 
Our profit outlook remains strong with the expectations for 7% to 11% growth in adjusted OIBDA and strong gains in adjusted EPS. As noted, we're lowering our expected capital expenditures for the year to approximately $290 million, reflecting refine capital plans and lower expectations for real estate spending. Included in our capital expenditures of approximately $290 million is about $29 million for real estate. In addition, we're adjusting our free cash flow outlook to $340 million to $370 million, reflecting our revised outlook for CapEx and adjusted OIBDA and moderately higher cash taxes. 
In April, we received the $10 million cash advance on our insurance claims related to the Chilean earthquakes that will be reflected in our Q2 free cash flow. Although we do expect to receive additional insurance proceeds in the future, we're not including any in our cash flow forecast at this time as the size and timing of these receipts is uncertain. We haven't included estimates for potential incremental 2010 capital spending related to Chile as well, as we're still evaluating facility, planning and timing of remediation. Thanks, and I would now like to turn the call over to Bob.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brian and good morning, everyone. As Brian noted, our quarterly financial results came in as expected. Our internal revenue growth improved somewhat despite difficult comparisons and continued pressures from the economy on service revenues. We con
componenttext:
Thanks, Brian and good morning, everyone. As Brian noted, our quarterly financial results came in as expected. Our internal revenue growth improved somewhat despite difficult comparisons and continued pressures from the economy on service revenues. We continue to deliver strong profit growth and cash flow. Overall, Q1 was a solid start for the year and we're on track towards delivering strong financial performance this year. 
Key messages that you should hear on today's update. First, our financial performance remains strong. This performance reflect the strength of our business model and the gains that we continue to drive to our focus on operational excellence across our business.
We're working on improving our growth trajectory, driving aggressively against new business with positive early results. This emphasis will help offset continued pressures on service activity and the impact from select factors such as the earthquake in Chile. 
Third, we're making good progress against our strategic priorities, including driving growth and improved returns in our International business, expanding our technology services offering and continuing to strengthen our organization.
Let me start by providing an update on our growth agenda. We're making progress on the growth front despite some continued headwinds in the business. Our quarterly growth performance was in line with the expectations. Storage growth, a key financial driver for Iron Mountain, was solid at 4%. As expected, we saw some moderation in storage growth in Q1 reflecting impacts from lower new sales levels and higher destructions during 2009. Destructions have stabilized, we're working on driving new sales, and believe we're on track towards achieving our full year objectives to storage revenues. 
Overall, internal growth was also 4% as benefits from factors like higher paper pricing offset continued pressures on core service activity. Service activity softens substantially during the economic downturn, and we continue to see lower transportation and shredding service levels, which are offsetting gains we are realizing in areas like DMS.
We are focused on strengthening our growth trajectory as we work through the year on factors that are in our control. In this context, we have concentrated efforts within our organization on capturing the large unmended opportunities we see in our business. We have a number of programs targeting and driving improved growth and extended our field leadership on supporting this effort with the same rigor that they used to drive operational excellence. 
We're of course, also working on improving our growth rate in Digital. We've added new services like eVantage to address evolving customer requirements. For eDiscovery services, we've added Classify & Collect that allows our PC backup customers to easily identify data, which is subject to legal hold and we've expanded the storage capacity in our server backup offering, all of which will help strengthen our recurring storage pipeline and overall revenue.
While it's still very early, we're making progress on the new sales front. We've landed new business opportunities in the data protection space, improved our competitiveness and strength, and our field organization is driving increased pipeline activity in records management. 
In digital, we're strengthening our subscription sales pipeline, which will drive benefits in terms of recurring revenue gains. We've got work to do, but we feel positive about this early progress towards improving our new sales performance.
As we focus on improving growth trends in the near term, we're also advancing on our long-term strategic agenda. As seen in our quarterly results, we continue to drive strong operating performance in our core North American operations. The business is running well. And a key area of Iron Mountain involves extending this operating capability to drive growth and improve returns in our international operations. As we have noted, this is an area where we are driving improved momentum and one that will be a key factor supporting strong financial performance in 2010 and beyond.
We're on track for strong performance in our International business this year, and we've begun deploying the North American label [ph] for operational excellence in our more developed international markets, such as the UK and Australia. Productivity gains in these markets will enable continued investment against global expansion, while driving strong profit gains. We're pleased with the capability and progress we're advancing on this front, and see this as an area where we can continue to build upon for the long term. We're emphasizing the expansion of technology service as a key driver of our long-term strategy as well. 
As noted on our year-end call, we recently completed the acquisition of Mimosa Systems. Mimosa provides enterprise-class, on-premise archiving services so organizations can better benefit from business continuity, compliance and litigation readiness. Mimosa deploys next generation technology and compliments our existing suite of digital products.  With Mimosa, Iron Mountain now has the ability to store enterprise information wherever it resides, whether it's at the customer location or ours, offering them increased choice and flexibility for managing their information. The integration of Mimosa is going well and Mimosa's CEO, T.M. Ravi,has agreed to become the Head of Marketing for our Digital business.
This expansion of our technology services offerings helps to strengthen our Digital business, and also helps to strengthen our value proposition across all our service lines. See, our customers records and information management challenges are not neatly arranged into files by format. They're struggling to manage the risks and costs associated with information growth across all formats, and are looking to solution providers with a broad range of expertise and capability for much needed help. 
Iron Mountain is uniquely positioned to capture this opportunity because we work across all formats and have more experience in managing records. The development of our technology services portfolio is positioning us well to deliver long-term growth across our business. We're on the right track strategically, as we remain focused on solving our customers' biggest information management challenges.
Expanding our talent base is another key statistic theme for our business. This is a focus that exists for us from our frontline operations to the Board of Directors. And in March, we welcomed Al Verrecchia, Chairman of Hasbro to our Board of Directors. Al led a highly successful transformation of Hasbro, and we'll certainly benefit from his executive leadership on our Board. Overall, we're making good progress against our strategic agenda.
Now before I conclude my remarks, Brian have mentioned the financial impact of the Chilean earthquake. Chile has been always been a great business for Iron Mountain, and their response to this disaster has only been further distinguished their greatness. All 850 of our employees are safe. We've coordinated a worldwide effort around Iron Mountain to help them, help our customers, and those round-the-clock efforts have also included providing local humanitarian aid. We're very proud of their performance. 
But before I take your questions, let me summarize. We had a solid quarter that was in line with our expectations. We're on track towards delivering strong financial performance this year. We were concentrating our efforts around an improved growth trajectory, while advancing our long-term strategic priorities to capture the potential we see for our business. 
Thanks, and now we'll open the phone lines and take your questions.

componenttext: Kevin, as you know, we talked at our investor day about a longer-term goal in the range of 9%. We still think that that's a good longer-term goal. We're a bit below that currently. We may see some moderate increases from the current levels over time as storage growth improves, which is our plan. But we think that, that 9% level, that longer-term goal is still a good goal for us.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know you discussed it a little bit, if you could just clarify for me a little bit. The $10 million negative impact from the earthquakes in Chile, what did that relate to?
componenttext: I know you discussed it a little bit, if you could just clarify for me a little bit. The $10 million negative impact from the earthquakes in Chile, what did that relate to?

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we highlighted two impacts. One was on revenue, which we estimate for the full year to be about $5 million and on OIBDA, a range of $5 million to $10 million. And the impact on the revenue is just expectations for some decreased service activity and
componenttext: Yes, we highlighted two impacts. One was on revenue, which we estimate for the full year to be about $5 million and on OIBDA, a range of $5 million to $10 million. And the impact on the revenue is just expectations for some decreased service activity and some lost storage revenues, some of the records that were impacted. Basically, there's some record sell over in the facilities. And when they get commingled with other records, we destroy them because we can't ensure their integrity. And so we're expecting some lost storage revenue. The profit impacts, obviously there's some impact from the lost business. We're also factoring in things like our insurance deductibles and some steps we took to strengthen our insurance coverage just given this was a significant event. Our claim will be sizable. We're very comfortable with our insurance coverage, but we took some conservative steps just to make sure that we have adequate coverage going forward.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Andrew Steinerman of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Andrew Steinerman of JPMorgan.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: With 4% internal growth on storage for the first quarter and 4% to 5% for the year, I was wondering if you think internal growth for storage is leaning forward? Like you gave comments about second quarter overall, but do you feel like storage will stay in
componenttext: With 4% internal growth on storage for the first quarter and 4% to 5% for the year, I was wondering if you think internal growth for storage is leaning forward? Like you gave comments about second quarter overall, but do you feel like storage will stay in this kind of 4% to 5% range in the year? If I quote you correctly, I thought I heard you say that the higher level of destructions have now stabilized.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct. A couple of things, Andrew. As far as next quarter, we're expecting storage growth in a similar range to Q1 as we've noted. But we're still working through some of the tougher comparisons, and those comparisons should ease later this year.
componenttext: That's correct. A couple of things, Andrew. As far as next quarter, we're expecting storage growth in a similar range to Q1 as we've noted. But we're still working through some of the tougher comparisons, and those comparisons should ease later this year. In terms of some of the key factors, destructions have stabilized. So they're still at healthy levels, but the trend had been going up. And we feel comfortable that things are moving in a better direction than they were. And a key factor that's going to help us on improving the storage growth rate over time is going to be progress in the new sales front. I think the -- good results in that area, and that will take some time to flow through of course. But we're feeling positive about our early [ph] progress.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm particularly pleased, Andrew, with the progress that we have in generating new sales. The field leadership, I mentioned this briefly in my comments, has really been able to pivot and focus on driving new revenue. And we've got an awful lot in a p
componenttext: Yes. I'm particularly pleased, Andrew, with the progress that we have in generating new sales. The field leadership, I mentioned this briefly in my comments, has really been able to pivot and focus on driving new revenue. And we've got an awful lot in a pipeline that is expanding. The quota performance year-over-year is much stronger. And the fact is, we've got the North American operation running very well, and it allows us to just become much more external in our focus in driving new revenue.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll also highlight our international storage is growing mid- to high-single digit based on some of the progress we'd made in areas like Continental Europe and expansion markets. Australia's doing quite well. So we feel we're on a good path. As you know,
componenttext: I'll also highlight our international storage is growing mid- to high-single digit based on some of the progress we'd made in areas like Continental Europe and expansion markets. Australia's doing quite well. So we feel we're on a good path. As you know, it takes a little time for the growth rates to change in storage, but we think we're moving this in the right direction.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010

componenttext: So the flow-through benefits of this take some time, but the fact is we feel much better about new sales this year than we did this last year at this time.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Andrew, I know you appreciate this, but I think in terms of factors like the economy, we would expect the first things that we would see would be improvements in more discretionary spending, some of the project activity, things on the new sales front.
componenttext: And Andrew, I know you appreciate this, but I think in terms of factors like the economy, we would expect the first things that we would see would be improvements in more discretionary spending, some of the project activity, things on the new sales front. The next benefit, which will lag somewhat, but we would expect service activity to improve. And I think the last thing we would expect to see is kind of the flow-through of the economy for storage just given that it take some time for people to create the incremental records and to store them. We are an archival storage business. So it will have benefits over time, but I just want to caution about we're still working through some of the lag effects. And we think we're improving in the terms of our outlook in that context.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010

componenttext: I mean to summarize, we feel very good about what we can control in driving new business and believe that service activity will rebound as the economy rebounds. I mean you know how strong it was in 2008 as we entered the downturn.

Just a little bit more on what actually kind of weakened sequentially, and then how do we think about growth and how it does accelerate throughout the year.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we saw a greater pressure recently through the economic downturn. We obviously are a high value-added proposition for our customers. And premium services like rush delivery, there is a significant decline in that. And that cost focus has continued wi
componenttext: Yes, we saw a greater pressure recently through the economic downturn. We obviously are a high value-added proposition for our customers. And premium services like rush delivery, there is a significant decline in that. And that cost focus has continued with customers. I think that I'd also note that in some areas, we may not have been as competitive as we needed to be. We've been improving things like our pricing equation. I think in shredding, we may have steered that a little too far. We've been making some adjustments on that front. So net-net, we're still seeing soft activity. We're planning for that to continue in the near term. We do expect that to improve over time, but it will lag improvement in general economic activity. And we're going to be working through those comparisons for the next couple of quarters.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the IT side, we've just kind of generally been hearing comments about companies looking to increase their IT spend and kind of going through more of the IT refresh cycle. I think Gartner also recently increased their projections for IT spend.
componenttext: And then on the IT side, we've just kind of generally been hearing comments about companies looking to increase their IT spend and kind of going through more of the IT refresh cycle. I think Gartner also recently increased their projections for IT spend. Just kind of curious what you're seeing in terms of the time line for IT spending improvements, and has that really changed much recently?

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: So Andrea, kind of anecdotal feedback because I spend a lot of time with customers, I don't see IT budgets going up in any kind of a significant way. What we do see is the decapitalization of IT, which is favoring a services model, an outsourced model. Th
componenttext: So Andrea, kind of anecdotal feedback because I spend a lot of time with customers, I don't see IT budgets going up in any kind of a significant way. What we do see is the decapitalization of IT, which is favoring a services model, an outsourced model. The thing about a subscription model though is that it does -- while we were up 4% in 2009, if lag's coming in and it doesn't have a spiky effect on revenue, but we've had strong progress on new sales. And I feel very good about just from a macro perspective the fact that IT is going towards more of a "pay as you use" model. And that's a trend that a lot of players have to adjust to more dramatically than we do because it's always been our business model.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Gold of Sidoti.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Gold of Sidoti.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can we speak a little bit more, and I may have asked you this before, the Records Center Optimization productivity improvement program (sic) [Records Center Optimization Program], could you just -- again, sort of how you think about things domestically. I
componenttext: Can we speak a little bit more, and I may have asked you this before, the Records Center Optimization productivity improvement program (sic) [Records Center Optimization Program], could you just -- again, sort of how you think about things domestically. I know it's a moving target, and I know there's more to it, but sort of how far along we are on that. And then if we've gotten that off the ground overseas and sort of where we are there too.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have, David. So it's essentially, we move from market to market in driving productivity from the system. We've done that very well throughout North America. And we do it from the standpoint of sustainability. So we're adding new programs as well, so we
componenttext: We have, David. So it's essentially, we move from market to market in driving productivity from the system. We've done that very well throughout North America. And we do it from the standpoint of sustainability. So we're adding new programs as well, so we've kicked off a procurement initiative in the last quarter that will really focus on strengthening our gains and consistency across North America. We have begun exporting the playbook most notably to the U.K. but also to other mature markets like Australia. And we feel very good that over time, we can pursue North American like returns out of our mature international businesses. So it's in the muscle memory of the company, and that business is running very well, which is why we're particularly enthused about the potential to grow the business through new sales because of the fact that the business is running well. And we can be more external in our focus. This is something that we had to work on internally for years to get into this kind of a rhythm. But we feel very comfortable with where we are in that regards as it relates to Records Center Optimization, productivity throughout our business and realizing that on a sustainable basis.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is there much more in North America that we think we can squeeze out?
componenttext: Is there much more in North America that we think we can squeeze out?

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're continuing to roll out the process orientation, the process focus on how we manage the business. And as Bob noted, we're onto kind of a next phase of initiatives, areas like procurement. We see a lot of opportunity on our front-end org
componenttext: Well, I think we're continuing to roll out the process orientation, the process focus on how we manage the business. And as Bob noted, we're onto kind of a next phase of initiatives, areas like procurement. We see a lot of opportunity on our front-end organization, just how we interface with the customer and go to market. I'd highlight that we think there's efficiencies there. We do want to reinvest those efficiencies to accelerate growth. We think that's an opportunity for us to become more effective and efficient. And so we are committed to continuing to improve our profitability. We think we've established very good capability in areas like pricing and just our process approach to running the business to enable us to keep making progress as we move forward. And as an enterprise, we have other areas to help us drive margin improvement. Most notably, we think there's a significant opportunity in the International business. As you know, the margins there relative to our North American Physical business are currently quite a bit lower. Some of that's in the stage of development of that business and the investments we're making in expansion markets, but that also represents a significant opportunity for us and also our Digital business as that gains in scale. So we have a number of things that we believe can help us sustain strong profit performance ahead of revenue growth as we move forward.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and let's remember the primary driver behind this, right? While we always knew that we would be able to be more effective and therefore produce stronger operating margins as a result of pursuing uniformity, the primary driver was so that we would est
componenttext: Yes, and let's remember the primary driver behind this, right? While we always knew that we would be able to be more effective and therefore produce stronger operating margins as a result of pursuing uniformity, the primary driver was so that we would establish a level of value in the marketplace, that we could then drive through new sales and a value proposition that's really unmatched in our business.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Vance Edelson of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Vance Edelson of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, in terms of recycled paper, could you comment on what you're seeing on the front lines in terms of your ability to sell the paper as your volume builds? Are you able to secure favorable pricing? Can you work directly with large buyers of the commod
componenttext: First, in terms of recycled paper, could you comment on what you're seeing on the front lines in terms of your ability to sell the paper as your volume builds? Are you able to secure favorable pricing? Can you work directly with large buyers of the commodity, for example, or would you say you're essentially beholden to whatever the spot rate is?

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have relationships with companies like waste management, the significant partners, they help us manage that. That helps us to, I think, have a secure avenue for sales over time. Our pricing is impacted by the spot market, so we do see fluctuations in t
componenttext: We have relationships with companies like waste management, the significant partners, they help us manage that. That helps us to, I think, have a secure avenue for sales over time. Our pricing is impacted by the spot market, so we do see fluctuations in the pricing levels over time consistent with the market. But to get at your question, Vance, I mean we're quite comfortable in our ability to secure buyers for the paper.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And on the capital spending priorities going forward, would you say that will largely mirror the first quarter breakout, in other words, mainly storage and maybe half that amount on IT? Any changes to the mix anticipated?
componenttext: And on the capital spending priorities going forward, would you say that will largely mirror the first quarter breakout, in other words, mainly storage and maybe half that amount on IT? Any changes to the mix anticipated?

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our outlook for this year is similar to our long-range goals. I mean the bulk of our spending is related to storage systems that support growth, so that's physical and digital. And a smaller percentage of our spending is on things like IT and strategic in
componenttext: Our outlook for this year is similar to our long-range goals. I mean the bulk of our spending is related to storage systems that support growth, so that's physical and digital. And a smaller percentage of our spending is on things like IT and strategic initiatives infrastructure. But the bulk of our spending remains related to growth-oriented capital.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And speaking of growth-oriented capital, beyond the established international markets where you still you have room for growth, what's the latest in terms of international expansion in the brand new, less developed markets? What regions are you really loo
componenttext: And speaking of growth-oriented capital, beyond the established international markets where you still you have room for growth, what's the latest in terms of international expansion in the brand new, less developed markets? What regions are you really looking at to create a first time presence now?

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: To create a first time presence, Vance? You mean -- if you look where we're not, we're still not in Japan. We're not in Africa. We're not in the Middle East, and those are areas that we're always looking for the right joint venture partners, enter the mar
componenttext: To create a first time presence, Vance? You mean -- if you look where we're not, we're still not in Japan. We're not in Africa. We're not in the Middle East, and those are areas that we're always looking for the right joint venture partners, enter the market with. We're most successful when we go in with a local partner that loves the local market. China's an area where you could argue that we have some flags planted, but there's a lot of opportunity for us to improve our presence in that region. And we've recently brought on some talent that will help us do that.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in the more developed markets, is there room for contiguous expansion geographically? Or would you say to drive revenues, it's more a matter of increasing penetration and density in the geography that you already have?
componenttext: And in the more developed markets, is there room for contiguous expansion geographically? Or would you say to drive revenues, it's more a matter of increasing penetration and density in the geography that you already have?

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean specifically, if you look at Brazil, Russia and India, we have very good businesses that we think we can -- Brazil really, its economy is expected to move up the stack rank, if you will, in the next few years. And we think that's something tha
componenttext: Yes, I mean specifically, if you look at Brazil, Russia and India, we have very good businesses that we think we can -- Brazil really, its economy is expected to move up the stack rank, if you will, in the next few years. And we think that's something that we can take advantage of. Russia, we have a great business in our joint venture partners, and we're very pleased with the way that's going. Remember that there's a ton of room in Continental Europe as well. We're still in the early stages of scaling these individual countries because unlike North America, Spain is different from Germany, which is different from France. And those businesses still have a lot of room for improvement, and it's in a timescale measured in years. You'll see more improvement there than you will from markets where we're just entering.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Healy of Northcoast Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Healy of Northcoast Research.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to talk a little bit about the North American Physical revenue growth in the quarter. I was curious and hope you could give us a little bit of color in terms of maybe the components of growth, kind of how much you're seeing from activity levels a
componenttext: I wanted to talk a little bit about the North American Physical revenue growth in the quarter. I was curious and hope you could give us a little bit of color in terms of maybe the components of growth, kind of how much you're seeing from activity levels and creation and maybe how much you're seeing from a pricing standpoint.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just in terms of storage, it was solid. We know that it was 4%. We are getting benefits from pricing to support that, but we are driving positive volume as well. It's obviously moderated from what we're used to driven by some of the impacts last year, the
componenttext: Just in terms of storage, it was solid. We know that it was 4%. We are getting benefits from pricing to support that, but we are driving positive volume as well. It's obviously moderated from what we're used to driven by some of the impacts last year, the higher disruption rates and the softer new sales. But overall, we're continuing to drive solid storage revenue growth, and we're looking improve that as we move forward. The service activity was supported by a couple of factors, obviously, improved paper pricing. We are seeing very good growth on the DMS front. And those factors are offset by the softness that we see on service activity levels and also, kind of on a select basis, some of the more traditional project work that we have done that isn't related in managing hybrid records, which we think is indicative of just kind of softer activity in some of the sales pipeline that softened last year. But yes, on balance, it's solid growth, in line with what we were hoping to achieve. And we're working on the things that we think we can improve that over time and position us well for when we see some of the benefits of the economy improving.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Brian, I thought you mentioned to a prior question that the first thing you'd see is some of the discretionary parts of your business to show firming before other parts would. If you were to exclude the impact of recycled paper prices in that compleme
componenttext: And Brian, I thought you mentioned to a prior question that the first thing you'd see is some of the discretionary parts of your business to show firming before other parts would. If you were to exclude the impact of recycled paper prices in that complementary service line, would you be starting to see that kind of discretionary element of the business picking up or have you got to experience that?

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we are. We are seeing that. It was positive in the first quarter, and that was supported by DMS, also by our eDiscovery business. But that is a favorable factor. It's moving forward sequentially, I don't want to give you an impression it's turned ar
componenttext: Well, we are. We are seeing that. It was positive in the first quarter, and that was supported by DMS, also by our eDiscovery business. But that is a favorable factor. It's moving forward sequentially, I don't want to give you an impression it's turned around quickly. It's moving in the right direction. But those early indicators, we are seeing some of the positive factors. And I need to be the voice of caution here. I just want to make sure people know it takes a little time for some of the benefits to flow through our business. And we are going to be working through this in the next couple of quarters. But we do see some signs that it's moving in the right direction, and we're working on things that'll help to strengthen that.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, John. And there's the fact -- remember, we lag into the downturn, and we lag coming out of it. It's just the nature of our business model.
componenttext: Yes, John. And there's the fact -- remember, we lag into the downturn, and we lag coming out of it. It's just the nature of our business model.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then lastly just on those shredding side of the business. I thought you'd mentioned that you may have changed a little bit kind of the price and value proposition. Can you talk a little bit about maybe how that business performed, excluding recycled p
componenttext: And then lastly just on those shredding side of the business. I thought you'd mentioned that you may have changed a little bit kind of the price and value proposition. Can you talk a little bit about maybe how that business performed, excluding recycled paper prices, in the quarter and maybe what you think a realistic growth rate for that business could be this year?

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Why don't I start and let Bob add the color in the business. But the revenues in the business were up solidly in Q1 supported by paper. It's a little difficult to separate paper from the overall business because as you might imagine, the competitive
componenttext: Yes. Why don't I start and let Bob add the color in the business. But the revenues in the business were up solidly in Q1 supported by paper. It's a little difficult to separate paper from the overall business because as you might imagine, the competitive dynamic is that flows into the overall economics, and it influences how you would price your services and things of that nature. Our service revenues were down moderately. But overall, it was a good quarter for shredding. And we think we can have solid growth in that business this year again aided by some of the macro factors. Bob, do you want to talk about some of the dynamics?

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Listen, John, this is an area where I think we're constructively dissatisfied with the way we competed last year, and we think we allowed our competition some entry, and then we're being more aggressive now. And I believe we'll see the benefits of th
componenttext: Yes. Listen, John, this is an area where I think we're constructively dissatisfied with the way we competed last year, and we think we allowed our competition some entry, and then we're being more aggressive now. And I believe we'll see the benefits of that because we have a value proposition that is differentiated from that of our competition especially as it relates to chain of custody. And we have specific programs in place that allow our sales force to really attack the competition where -- we gave them a little bit of room last year, and we shouldn't have done that. But we're also working through channels here. So you can expect to see announcements from some of our partners specifically in the commercial real estate space and more to come on that. But where people see the usefulness of offering shredding to their customers whether it be in office space or other locations that we'll hope to announce later in the year.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Eric Boyer of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Eric Boyer of Wells Fargo.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I suspect that you want to but do you expect any change in seasonality patterns for total consolidated results now that the European business will have a calendar year end?
componenttext: Yes, I suspect that you want to but do you expect any change in seasonality patterns for total consolidated results now that the European business will have a calendar year end?

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not from the European change. In fact, one of the conclusions as we went through this process, which was a significant amount of effort for the team to kind of do the assessment on this and get us to a place where we're fully aligned in terms of our repor
componenttext: Not from the European change. In fact, one of the conclusions as we went through this process, which was a significant amount of effort for the team to kind of do the assessment on this and get us to a place where we're fully aligned in terms of our reporting globally when the conclusion was there wasn't really a material effect from the seasonality change. So that enables us to keep the change relatively simple and have a one-time charge flow through the other expense line. So the short answer is no. There shouldn't be an effect.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then with a situation like the winter weather that was experienced in the first quarter, will any of that revenue be pushed out into the second quarter or is the majority of that type of service, just service revenue lost?
componenttext: And then with a situation like the winter weather that was experienced in the first quarter, will any of that revenue be pushed out into the second quarter or is the majority of that type of service, just service revenue lost?

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hard to assess, but I wouldn't count on that being pushed out. I think that's related to normal activity that didn't happen, and we're not expecting to -- so that should be a benefit. I think the key thing on the service side to recognize, which we try to
componenttext: Hard to assess, but I wouldn't count on that being pushed out. I think that's related to normal activity that didn't happen, and we're not expecting to -- so that should be a benefit. I think the key thing on the service side to recognize, which we try to highlight is, one theme is the core service activity remains soft. And we're planning for that to continue particularly in the near term, that we are up against a couple of tough compares in Q2. We had a big project in Italy last year that was very beneficial. We'll work through the lapping on that. And we have a large license sale on digital. So there's a couple of factors that are going to moderate growth. Paper pricing came down 15%, so that's less of a benefit. But net-net, I think overall in the business, we feel good. We've got the storage moving on a good track. We're seeing some positive signs, and we're looking forward to getting through some of the transition phase here and getting to a stronger growth rate moving into 2011.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then with the subscription weakness within digital, which type of digital subscriptions would you expect to come back first? And are you seeing any positive signs that that's happening?
componenttext: And then with the subscription weakness within digital, which type of digital subscriptions would you expect to come back first? And are you seeing any positive signs that that's happening?

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're definitely seeing positive signs, Eric, as it relates to the pipeline specifically around eDiscovery. It's a very strong business for us. We're very, very pleased with Mimosa, and our backup offerings have become more competitive. I mentioned i
componenttext: Yes, we're definitely seeing positive signs, Eric, as it relates to the pipeline specifically around eDiscovery. It's a very strong business for us. We're very, very pleased with Mimosa, and our backup offerings have become more competitive. I mentioned it quickly in my remarks, but we've added capability to our backup offerings that we think opens up the market opportunity for us. And we're seeing the right progress out of our sales force as it relates to driving increased activity in the pipeline. We have enough analytics on that to know that it will flow through. Keep in mind, it's the subscription model, right? So we don't get the lumps that comes positively or negatively with being a perpetual license business that you'll find in many technology companies.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Year-on-year, we're seeing solid growth in the subscription pipeline, so we'll look for that to benefit our results going forward.
componenttext: Year-on-year, we're seeing solid growth in the subscription pipeline, so we'll look for that to benefit our results going forward.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010

componenttext: We don't report on a granular basis. And we're pleased with the progress that we're making on that front. Financial services is obviously a big vertical for us, and I would not highlight that we're seeing substantially different trends across our verticals. I think they're relatively consistent in the business. But our. . .

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're on the right track though as it relates to the kind of opportunity we face. We see a lot of usefulness and are building our organization to really drive depth into those industries that are highly regulated with a lot of knowledge workers, so think
componenttext: You're on the right track though as it relates to the kind of opportunity we face. We see a lot of usefulness and are building our organization to really drive depth into those industries that are highly regulated with a lot of knowledge workers, so think financial services, health care, legal. And you can see through our service offerings that we're becoming more verticalized. And you can expect that we'll become more verticalized in our approach to the market over time, but we don't expect to break out the results specifically by quarter.

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: My follow-on question actually was the fuel prices are up like year-over-year quite significantly. If you guys can just give us some color on like overall energy cost?
componenttext: My follow-on question actually was the fuel prices are up like year-over-year quite significantly. If you guys can just give us some color on like overall energy cost?

headline: Iron Mountain Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2010
componenttextpreview: Overall energy costs remain in the 2% to 3% range. It wasn't a big driver of our margins one way or the other. And I would just highlight, keep in mind, to the degree that energy costs go up, we do get the benefit of fuel surcharges, which have not been m
componenttext: Overall energy costs remain in the 2% to 3% range. It wasn't a big driver of our margins one way or the other. And I would just highlight, keep in mind, to the degree that energy costs go up, we do get the benefit of fuel surcharges, which have not been material in recent quarters. But if we saw consistent increases on that front, we'd have some ability to offset that with the fuel surcharges.
